comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: Sir George Houstoun Reid, GCB, GCMG, KC (25 February 1845 – 12 September 1918) the Premier of New South Wales and fourth Prime Minister of Australia. He was married to Flora Ann Brumby. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Reid_(Australian_politician)

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: See www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2851188434/ Could be at same event.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: A possibility for this John Barrett is the diplomat who was a director general of the Panamerican Union. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Barrett_(diplomat)

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Yes, it is the diplomat John Barrett. The Library of Congress has other photos of him. hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pan.6a25060 hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/cph.3b30493 hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.07062

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: "In the winter of 1917-18 [Reid] made a semi-official speaking tour of the United States of America for the war effort, but became ill at St Louis in February and again in April after returning to London. In July he took part in a debate on Irish affairs, moving an important amendment to defuse a motion condemning the government's policy. He died on 13 September 1918 of cerebral thrombosis, survived by his wife, who the previous year had been appointed G.B.E. for work on behalf of convalescent servicemen, and their two sons and daughter." -- Australian Dictionary of Biography Online
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Reid was in the United States in 1912 (when he was the first Australian High Commissioner in England), according to the NYT on September 19, 1912: AUSTRALIA TROUBLED BY CITY CONGESTION; Sir George Reid, High Commissioner, Says There Is a Rush of Immigrants from England. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C06E5D6123CE633A... And he came again in the Spring of 1913 for the Anglo-American Peace Centenary. See NYT for April 23, 1913: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=940CE7DA173FE6...

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: According to a report about the visit of the Reids in Washington in The Washington herald., October 03, 1912, Page 6, Col. 4 was among the guests at a luncheon a Dr. Cook Adams of Chicago. The New York Times, September 22, 1912 col. 3 mentions a Dr. G. Cooke Adams of Chicago among the guests of another dinner in honor of Sir G. Reid. This is most likely the same person who published a study of cancer in Chicago, see The New York Times, September 24, 1907. The autor, Dr. G. Cooke Adams was according to that originally from London and formerly from Australia. In 1904, he wrote a study about cancer in Australia (www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0140673601874936).

comment.author: 33593953@N02
comment._content: B-59: Thanks for the further sleuthing! We'll add the probable identification of Dr. Cooke Adams when we next update the description.
